Chapter 38: The Heaven of Pure Abode (13) Bodhisattva Necklace Sutra, Chapter 38: The Heaven of Pure Abode At that time, when the World-Honored One was expounding this chapter on the turning and non-turning of the Dharma with Manjushri, there was a celestial son of the Heaven of Pure Abode who had cultivated various merits under innumerable buddhas of the past, served and made offerings to the buddhas of the world, gone from one buddha land to another, mastered the treasury of the Dharma, had unobstructed eloquence, practiced great compassion, attained the nature of emptiness, and temporarily manifested birth in the heavens in order to save the celestials. He immediately rose from his seat, adjusted his robes, and stood up majestically with his retinue.
At that time, the celestial son went to where the Buddha was, bowed his head at the Buddha's feet, and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!

We celestials have planted meritorious blessings in the past and now have been born in the heavens, enjoying the five pleasures by ourselves. Our attendants naturally respond to us. Playing in the bathing pools, our happiness is immeasurable. What blessings have we cultivated to be born in the heavens?

My palace is forty-nine yojanas in size, with seven-jeweled halls and towers, and beyond that is a bathing pond surrounded by seven jeweled trees in seven layers. What merit did I cultivate to attain such blessings?
At that time, the World-Honored One told the Heavenly Son of Pure Abode:
Excellent, excellent!
Heavenly Son!
You are able to ask about this meaning in the presence of the Tathagata. I will now explain it to you one by one. Consider it well!
The Buddhas of the past, as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, also spoke of this meaning. The Buddhas of the present and future will also expound this subtle Dharma.
What do you think?
Heavenly Son!
I will now ask you, and you should answer me one by one.
Can you remember the past Heavenly Sons who resided in your heaven?
He replied:
No, I cannot.
World-Honored One!
The names and titles of the past Heavenly Sons cannot be recorded.
What do you think, Heavenly Son?
Is your present body permanent or impermanent?
Is your present body permanent or impermanent?
The celestial son replied:
My present body is a permanent dharma, not an impermanent dharma.
The Buddha further told the celestial son:
If your present body is a permanent dharma, where are the past celestial beings now?
He replied:
They have perished.
The Buddha said:
What do you think?
Celestial son!
Since the past celestial beings have all perished, how can your present body exist?
The celestial son replied:
The past buddhas have all entered nirvana. How did the World-Honored One come into being today?
The Buddha told the celestial son:
Are the past buddhas and my present body the same or not?
The celestial son replied:
No, it is not.ğŸ”½
Why is it so?
The past buddhas, in the past, were the present of the past.
How can you say that all past Buddhas have entered parinirvÄá¹‡a?
The celestial son asked again:ğŸ”½Are there three time periods?
Or are there no three time periods?
The Buddha replied to the celestial son:
There is the name of three time periods, but the activities of the three time periods are different.
The celestial son asked again:
The TathÄgata now speaks of past Buddhas, and I do not doubt it.
He also speaks of the present Buddhas in the ten directions, and I also do not doubt it.

The World-Honored One replied:
What you ask me now, do you ask about the three time periods of the past?ğŸ”½Do you ask about the three time periods of the present?
Or do you ask about the three time periods of the future?

I also do not ask about the three time periods of the past, the three time periods of the present, or the three time periods of the future. Today I only ask about the Buddhas of the three time periods.
How can you speak of a Buddha in the future?
The Buddha told the celestial son:
The future Buddha has two causes and conditions.
What are the two?

There may be past buddhas, tathÄgatas, arhats, perfectly enlightened ones, who practice great compassion and are endowed with the major marks, practicing skillful means, entering the five paths, teaching and transforming sentient beings without destroying the Dharma realm.

Again, appearing in the world, they may be BrahmÄ Heaven or manifest the body of Åšakra, concealing the appearance of the Buddha. This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva becoming a buddha in the future.

Although they have not yet become buddhas and are not yet endowed with the major marks, they may take on the body of a deity or a ghost without destroying the Dharma realm. This is called, Heavenly Son!
Becoming a buddha in the future has these causes and conditions.
Furthermore, Heavenly Son!
The past buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, also have two causes and conditions.
What are the two?
Attaining the samÄdhi of the lion's majestic power, in a secluded place with no attachments in the mind, one contemplates the immeasurable merits of the ten dharmas.
What are the ten kinds?
This bodhisattva cultivates the dharmas contemplated by the buddhas, the world-honored ones. This is called the practice of inexhaustibility.
Furthermore, son of heaven!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva discriminates all the dharmas of the TathÄgata. This is called the practice of inexhaustibility.
Furthermore, son of heaven!
The bodhisattva teaches and transforms sentient beings, all of whom aspire to the unsurpassed true path. This is called the practice of inexhaustibility.
Furthermore, son of heaven!

The bodhisattva discriminates the immeasurable buddha-realms, purifies the buddha-lands, teaches and transforms sentient beings without destroying wisdom, and accomplishes the dharmas as contemplated. This is called the practice of inexhaustibility.
Furthermore, son of heaven!

The bodhisattva practices the precepts as the Buddha-World-Honored One does, cultivates the Dharma of liberation, and through these precepts teaches and transforms immeasurable sentient beings, all of whom give rise to the unsurpassed true Way. This is called the practice of inexhaustibility.

At that time, the evil mÄra PÄpÄ«yÄn creates various transformations to frighten the Buddha, sometimes with a human head and animal body, sometimes with an animal head and human body, sometimes with four eyes, eight eyes, up to a hundred thousand eyes, sometimes transforming into a monkey, tiger, or leopard to frighten the Buddha, but the Buddha's mind is as unshakable as the earth. If good men and good women give rise to a vast vow, filling the trichiliocosm, their wisdom and contemplation are also inexhaustible, their sound and resonance flow freely without obstruction, discerning the sounds and resonances of all sentient beings, perhaps with a single sound responding to hundreds of thousands of myriads of sounds, all expounding the teachings of the Way, universally benefiting all kinds of sentient beings. If good men and good women, in a single lifetime, leave the household life to study the path, shave their beards and hair, uphold the precepts, purify their bodies, and delight the multitude with what they delight in, this is called the fifth signless Dharma.
Furthermore, Prince!

If good men and good women, by nature, practice in accord with emptiness, come and go from emptiness in immeasurable and limitless ways, never acting for their own sake but transforming and educating sentient beings, transcending emptiness without obstruction, this is called the sixth signless Dharma.

If good men and good women, in all sentient beings, walk alone without obstruction, in the wisdom of all dharmas expound the meaning of penetrating insight, sitting and emitting light reaching the innumerable worlds of the ten directions, either attaining nirvana and manifesting the meaning of impermanence, either remaining or disappearing, either showing the excellent characteristics or concealing the excellent characteristics, in the midst of this teaching and transforming innumerable sentient beings and purifying the Buddha-lands, this is called the seventh dharma of no characteristics.

If good men and good women, there is also penetrating insight called subduing demons, those who attain this samÄdhi subdue the four demons:

desire, love, death, and the heavenly demon, causing bodhisattvas to rely on this dharma and attain accomplishment. Those who wish to be the Dharma King and be foremost should first practice this samÄdhi of subduing demons. This is called the eighth dharma of no characteristics.
Furthermore, Prince!

If good men and good women thoroughly study all dharmas, deeply penetrate the essentials, and fully possess the roots of goodness, they will also enable immeasurable sentient beings to enter this essential, see the power of the bodhisattvas, and increase the contemplation of cessation. They have already exhausted the dharma of non-arising and non-cessation.

Although they see appearances, they are originally without appearances. Sitting and lying, they contemplate the various practices of the bodhisattvas. These are called the nine dharmas without characteristics.

If good men and good women fully possess the basis of the ten wholesome [deeds].
What are the ten?

The three [wholesome deeds] of body, the four [wholesome deeds] of speech, and the three [wholesome deeds] of mind. They have mastery over the various dharmas and are not attached to existence. They delight in immeasurable non-action, and are also able to delight in immeasurable hundreds of thousands of concentrations. In each concentration, they transform immeasurable sentient beings.
These are called the ten dharmas without characteristics.

One who practices the Dharma should practice non-Dharma, non-action is action, and non-observation is observation. This is called the supreme practice among the practices of the king, praised by all Buddhas, performing Buddha-works, and having no equal.
At that time, the celestial son again said to the Buddha:
What is it?
World-Honored One!
The Buddhas of the three times have no three times. As the World-Honored One has said, the Buddhas of the past return to the present, and the Buddhas of the present return to the future.

This meaning is not so.
Why is it so?
The past has already ceased, and expediently returns to the present. The present has not yet moved, and again speaks of the future. The characteristics of the many dharmas are contradictory.

At that time, the World-Honored One said:
Excellent, excellent!
Son of a good family!
What you have asked now is all due to the Buddha's majestic spiritual power, enabling you to ask about this meaning.
Listen carefully, listen carefully, and consider it well!
I will explain it to you one by one.
The celestial son said:
I accept the teaching!
It is so.
World-Honored One!
The Buddha told the celestial son:
How is the past the past?
The celestial son said to the Buddha:

It is called the past because it gradually arises and ceases. Yesterday's form is not today's form, so it is called the past. Yesterday's body is not today's body, so it is called the past. Yesterday's strength is not today's strength, so it is called the past.
At that time, the World-Honored One asked the celestial son again:
What do you think, son of a good family?
Are the perceptions and knowledge of the body different?
The celestial son said to the Buddha:
No, World-Honored One!
The Buddha asked again:
Are name and form and feeling different?
The celestial son said to the Buddha:
No, World-Honored One!
The Buddha asked again:
Is there a difference between the path to liberation and the ultimate path?
He replied:
No, World-Honored One!
The Buddha told the celestial son:
Stop, stop!
Son of noble family!
The Buddha's treasury is vast, not within your realm.
The wisdom of the past is limited, the wisdom of the present is limited, and the wisdom of the future is limited.
Why is this?

All dharmas arise from dharmas, and dharmas cease due to dharmas. Originally there are no dharmas, no past, future, or present, and also no good or bad conduct in this world or the next, and also no sages who attain fruition. This is what is meant, son of noble family!
How can you say there are dharmas of the three times?
At that time, the celestial son again said to the Buddha:
How do the names of the three times arise?
How do they cease?
The Buddha told the celestial son:
Birth is originally non-birth, and cessation is originally non-cessation. All dharmas are also like this - birth is originally non-birth, and cessation is originally non-cessation.
Why is this?
Because their nature is naturally empty.
At that time, the celestial son again addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
Is the TathÄgata in birth today?
Or is he in non-birth?
The Buddha told the celestial son:
The body of the TathÄgata is in the past, future, and present, and is neither in birth nor in non-birth. Therefore, there is no past, future, or present.
The celestial son addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
Is it only the TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One who has no birth in the past, future, and present?
Are all dharmas completely without birth?
The Buddha told the celestial son:
All dharmas are completely without birth. I do not see birth, nor do I see non-birth.
The celestial son said to the Buddha:
The life-span of humans, the fundamental existence of sentient beings, up to the six perfections - are they born or not born?
Are they born or not born?
The Buddha told the celestial son:
When arising is not seen, non-arising is also not seen. All dharmas are unattainable and self-accomplished, therefore they are said to be unborn.

The buddhas of the three times have no desires, no defilements, and are neither born nor not born, therefore they have no arising. The same is true for the attainment of samÄdhi. Because nothing is said, there is no teaching.
The celestial son said to the Buddha:
Are the four foundations and the four paths born or not born?
Are they born or not born?
The Buddha told the celestial son:
The four foundations and the four paths are originally unborn, let alone being born now.
They will also not be born in the future.
At that time, the celestial son said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
Are the stages of purity, nature, thinness, non-arising, and absence of desire, anger, and ignorance born or not born?
Are they born or not born?
The Buddha told the celestial son:

From the stage of acceptance and grasping up to all dharmas, form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness, delusion, craving, contact, up to birth, old age, sickness, and death, from the stream-enterer up to the unsurpassed path, are neither born nor not born.
At that time, the celestial son said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
How are they born?
How are they not born?
The Buddha told the celestial son:
One who attains the perfection of mental freedom does not see birth or non-birth.
The celestial son said to the Buddha:
How is the perfection of mental freedom neither born nor not born?
The Buddha told the celestial son:
From this shore to the other shore, I do not see any sentient beings who are born or who cease to be, nor do I see any nests or abodes. Therefore, I also do not see birth and I do not see non-birth.
The celestial son said to the Buddha:
Are all dharmas and the TathÄgata's body in birth or non-birth?
Are they in non-birth?
The Buddha told the celestial son:
They are in birth and they are in non-birth, but I do not see birth and I do not see non-birth. Therefore, the Buddha of the Three Times is also not in birth and is also not in non-birth.
The Buddha told the celestial son:

If good sons and good women attain this penetrating wisdom and concentration, and understand that all dharmas are neither in birth nor in non-birth, the TathÄgata's sutra Dharma is also like this, neither in birth nor in non-birth.
Why is it so?
All dharmas are without attachment, without bondage, and without liberation. Therefore, they subdue the four demons.
The Buddha further told the celestial sons:
If there are good sons and good women who accomplish wisdom, they will be able to perfect all dharmas and will further cultivate ten dharmas.
What are the ten?
First, they should be close to good and virtuous friends and seek to be their companions;
Second, they should practice great compassion and extend it to all;
Third, they should fulfill the wishes of others according to their thoughts;
Fourth, they should purify all realms and sever the fetters and afflictions;
Fifth, they should cultivate the pure path and take on the heavy responsibility for others;
Sixth, they should bear the sufferings of others without criticizing those who receive them;ğŸ”½Seventh, they should teach ignorant people and instruct them in the essentials of the right path;
Eighth, they should teach the ignorant and deluded to have faith in the right path;
Ninth, they should accord with the Dharma and not criticize those who receive it;
Tenth, they should single-mindedly uphold the Dharma and not associate with the heterodox.
This is what is meant, son of noble family!
If good men and good women cultivate the true Dharma and attain this samÄdhi, they will be able to fully possess all dharmas.
At that time, the World-Honored One again told the celestial sons:
If there are men and women who respect their teachers, they should further cultivate ten unobstructed dharmas.
What are the ten unobstructed dharmas?
First, traveling to the ten directions to pay homage to the buddhas - this is called the first unobstruction for sons and daughters of the clan;
Second, in all wisdom, being neither bound nor liberated, and contemplating the Dharma of cessation - the second unobstruction;
Third, in all suffering and joy, the mind is tranquil and extinguished - the third unobstruction;
Fourth, in a solitary place, contemplating meditation and concentration, the mind is not confused or disturbed - the fourth unobstruction;
Fifth, the seven essential paths of the bodhisattva Dharma are neither increased nor decreased - the fifth unobstruction;
Sixth, all forms originally do not exist, and their coming is not seen - the sixth unobstruction;
Seventh, calculating that the original formlessness does not have birth and cessation, understanding and knowing impermanence, is the seventh unobstructed;
Eighth, single-mindedly entering concentration, the Way is originally natural and not attached to various dharmas;
Ninth, a single thought and a single practice accord with the Dharma and are not in opposition;
Tenth, not being in the internal or the external, naturally arising and ceasing, is the tenth unobstructed.
Thus, son of noble family!
If good sons and good women discern and contemplate the ten unobstructed, they will be able to fully possess all dharmas.
The Buddha told the celestial son:
If there are good sons and good women who, in a single moment of thought, are able to fully possess all dharmas, they should cultivate the ten dharmas of the foremost meaning of eloquence.
What are the ten?
First, the wisdom of birth, the wisdom of exhaustion, and the wisdom of non-birth and non-cessation;
Second, the four equalities are impartial, without the thought of self;
Third, being joyful and at ease, guarding oneself and not losing the four convictions;
Fourth, what is said is agreeable and does not go against one's original vow;
Fifth, the mind of the Way is firmly established, and the Dharma is accomplished according to the Dharma, and one's right view does not go against one's original characteristics;
Sixth, one cultivates the six profound dharmas, which are originally without characteristics;
Seventh, one treats enemies and friends equally, without right or wrong;
Eighth, one has single-minded faith and understands one's original birth;
Ninth, one expounds the various dharmas without conceptualizing the dharmas;
Tenth, one's vajra-like concentration does not destroy the nature as it is.
This is what is meant, son of noble family!
If good sons and good women possess these ten dharmas, they will be able to fully possess all dharmas.
The Buddha further said to the celestial son:
Good sons and good women who cultivate the ten Dharma-offerings without conceptualizing giving are able to fully possess all dharmas.
What are the ten?

Fifth, examining the mind and cultivating the path, forever free from attachment;

Eighth, skillfully causing others to be unaware;
Ninth, manifesting the correct Dharma and revealing the light of wisdom;
Tenth, taking on the suffering of others without seeking recompense.
This is what is meant, Heavenly Son!
If good men and good women practice these ten kinds of giving, not giving rise to worldly thoughts, they will then be able to fully possess all dharmas.
Why is this?
The minds of these good men and good women are like vajra, indestructible. The dharmas practiced by bodhisattvas are like this, also not known by Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.
The Buddha further told the Heavenly Son:
If good men and good women cultivate ten pure dharmas, they will be able to fully possess all dharmas.
What are the ten pure dharmas?
First, the Way should be pure; impurity is not the Way.
Second, the Way should be of one mind; many thoughts are not the Way.
Third, the Way should be content; much desire is not the Way.
Fourth, the Way should be respectful; arrogance is not the Way.
Fifth, the Way should restrain the mind; indulgence is not the Way.
Sixth, the Way should be radiant; self-concealment is not the Way; the sixth is repeated from the third.

Eighth, the Way should be enlightened; delusion is not the Way.
Ninth, the Way should teach and transform; stinginess is not the Way.

This is called, Heavenly Son!
If good men and good women cultivate these ten dharmas, they will be able to perfect all dharmas.

Just as the sunlight forever dispels darkness and illuminates the people of the world, each obtaining eyes, so too are bodhisattvas. By practicing these ten dharmas, they are able to perfect all dharmas.
Heavenly Son, you should know, just as genuine gold is clear both inside and out, and whatever vessels it is used to make are all accomplished.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. Internally, they are free from defilements, and externally, they illuminate. They are also like space, universally covering everything.
Bodhisattvas are also like this. Cultivating these ten dharmas, they also have no thoughts:
'I have something to accomplish, teaching and transforming sentient beings to sever all attachments.'
Furthermore, Heavenly Son!
It is just like Mount Sumeru, which is made of the four treasures. Mount Sumeru also has no thought:
'I am made of the four treasures, standing in the center of the four oceans.'
The bodhisattva's attainment of the four unobstructed eloquences is also like this, not thinking of these eloquences as spoken in accordance with the Dharma.
Why is it so?
Because there is originally no thought.
It is just like the great earth universally supporting myriad things, with trees, flowers, fruits, and various herbs all growing.
The earth also does not think:
I can accomplish and nurture all things.
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva is also like this, not thinking:
I transform sentient beings, practice great compassion, go from one buddha land to another buddha land, and protect all those who are not yet liberated.

Heavenly son, you should know that it is just like the four great oceans producing various treasures, and all sentient beings who go to collect treasures return as they please. The oceans also do not think:
I give birth to various treasures and provide them to sentient beings.
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva is also like this, rescuing suffering people and providing them with the seven treasures.
The so-called seven treasures are the seven factors of enlightenment. Bodhisattvas also do not think like this:
'I give the treasure of the seven factors of enlightenment, with wholesome roots complete, adorning the Buddha tree, and adorned with various good qualities.'
Why is it so?
Because there is originally no conceptual thought.
Heavenly son, you should know that just as the Dharma realm gives rise to all dharmas, great compassion, and the six pÄramitÄs,
the Dharma realm also does not think like this:
'I give rise to all dharmas, great compassion, and the six pÄramitÄs.'
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. They give rise to all dharmas to teach and transform sentient beings, but they also do not think to say:
'I have something to liberate.'
Heavenly son, you should know that it is just like a bhiká¹£u in samÄdhi who eliminates various conceptual thoughts and the mind does not move.
The bhiká¹£u in samÄdhi also does not think like this:
'I now enter samÄdhi with spiritual powers and self-mastery.'
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. Whatever Dharma they think of, they all accomplish it. What they say is true and sincere, not violating their original vow.
Heavenly Son, you should know that it is just like a diamond that cannot be destroyed.
Why is it so?
It is because its inherent nature is like that.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. They accord with the nature of dharmas and do not lose the original limit.
It is just like a bright pearl that illuminates widely. The bright pearl also does not think like this:
'I have something to illuminate, causing sentient beings to see its light.'
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this.
It is just like a person who has attained the path of the immortals, whose mind has what it wishes for and can accomplish everything.
That person with the five supernatural powers also does not think like this:
'What I now think of is all accomplished.'
Bodhisattvas are also like this.
It is just like a skilled person who is good at the six arts, who may use a sword or a spear to destroy a large crowd.
That skilled person also does not think like this:
'What I am doing now is the best among people, subduing the great assembly, and there is no one who can equal me.'
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. Entering immeasurable samÄdhi and attaining concentration, they move the trichiliocosm, but they do not boast, saying:
'I have this spiritual power, moving all the worlds without exception.'

It is just like a wheel-turning sage king who originally cultivated the ten wholesome deeds and the five precepts, fully ruling the trichiliocosm, with a thousand brave sons and possessing the seven treasures, and all the small kings of the various countries come to pay their respects.
At that time, the wheel-turning sage king also does not think like this:
'Now my many virtues are complete, my physical characteristics are majestic, and I rule the four continents.'
Why is it so?
It is because the nature of merit is like this, not contradicting each other.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. Cultivating the bodhisattva path and respectfully following the Buddha's teachings, they always engage in teaching and transforming, with gods and humans receiving grace, and the number of beings they liberate is immeasurable.
Why is this?
Bodhisattvas also do not have this thought:
I should liberate immeasurable beings and attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the nirvÄá¹‡a realm without remainder.
The nature of emptiness is such that there are no beings who can make it otherwise.

It is like farmers who plant according to the seasons without missing the right time. The previous seeds are not the later seeds, and the later seeds are not the previous seeds, each growing large and mutually accepting each other.
However, those seeds do not have this thought:
'I have something to give birth to, and they have something to lose.'
Why is this?
The inherent nature is such that there is no one who can make it otherwise.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. They study all dharmas and practice the bodhisattva path, and with the merit and virtue of the ten wholesome deeds, they purify the faculties of sentient beings and lead them all to the path of non-action.
At that time, the bodhisattva does not think like this:
I now have something to liberate and lead from here to the other shore.
Why is it so?
The fundamental nature is like this, and no one can make it otherwise.
It is just like sweet rain falling in a timely manner, and the hundred grains, grasses, and trees growing in a timely manner.
However, that cloud and rain do not think like this:
We have moisture and something to nurture.
Why is it so?
Because there is no mind originally.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. When the Dharma cloud rains down once, it universally moistens the trichiliocosm, enabling the various kinds of sentient beings to all obtain moisture, and not abandoning the fundamental vow to practice the bodhisattva path.
The bodhisattva also does not think like this:
'I can now let fall the rain of the Dharma, universally moistening the trichiliocosm, causing all sentient beings to attain enlightenment.'
Why is it so?
Because the mind of great vows is originally without thought, and its nature is spontaneous.
In this way, Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who enter this samÄdhi can cause sentient beings to attain ultimate purity, not just ordinary purity;
they can cause sentient beings to attain ultimate peace and security, not just ordinary peace and security;
they can cause sentient beings to reach the other shore, not just reach an ordinary shore;ğŸ”½they can cause sentient beings to attain liberation, not just ordinary liberation;
they can cause sentient beings to attain ultimate joy, not just ordinary joy;
they can cause sentient beings to sever their afflictions, not just ordinary severance;
they can cause sentient beings to dwell in the excellent field of merit, not just ordinary dwelling;
they can cause sentient beings to accept the offerings of faith from others and deliver all, not just ordinary acceptance and delivery;
It can cause sentient beings to enter the wise and holy Dharma-Vinaya, not others who can cause entry into the wise and holy Dharma-Vinaya;
It can cause sentient beings to stand in irreversible [progress toward Buddhahood], not others who can cause to stand in irreversible [progress toward Buddhahood];
It can cause sentient beings to attain omniscience and pervade the trichiliocosm, not others who can pervade the trichiliocosm;
It can cause sentient beings to become leaders for others, not others who can become leaders.
Why is it so?

Because bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas cultivate this samÄdhi, immeasurable Dharma practices pervade everywhere, causing them to be saved. It opens the Dharma-nature and the Dharma gate of vast vows, which is inconceivable, limitless, and vast. It is not for the sake of one person to purify the bodhisattva path, but universally for all difficult-to-save sentient beings, establishing them in unsurpassed liberation.
Sometimes, for the sake of saving one person, a bodhisattva would give up his life to undergo suffering on their behalf.
Some bodhisattvas, for the sake of one person, do not abandon them for eons, only after they are liberated do they themselves attain nirvana.

Some bodhisattvas, wishing to purify their own realm and sever all bonds and attachments, purify the fundamental [afflictions] of sentient beings and establish them in the pure, correct Dharma of liberation.
Moreover, there are bodhisattvas who uphold diligent practice and are not attached to heavenly blessings, always circulating through the five paths to teach and transform.
Some bodhisattvas attain the four forms of fearlessness, teaching and transforming sentient beings without harboring timidity.
Some bodhisattvas attain the four forms of ready speech, and when people come to question them, their principles are unobstructed.
Some bodhisattvas are able to expound the Dharma without being attached to fame and fortune or seeking benefits through flattery.
Some bodhisattvas attain the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateway, discerning the contemplation of dharmas and cultivating impure practices.
Some bodhisattvas attain the Buddha's samÄdhi, establishing omniscience without abandoning false thoughts.
Some bodhisattvas attain the Buddha's liberation, causing all people to leave the household life and study the path.
There are bodhisattvas who attain the wisdom of spiritual powers and practice skillful means to enter in accordance with forms.
There are bodhisattvas who attain the samÄdhi of formless observation, entering the realm of space and practicing the inconceivable.
There are bodhisattvas who attain the concentration of cessation, manifesting parinirvÄá¹‡a without abiding in nirvÄá¹‡a.
There are bodhisattvas who attain the seven contemplations, externally manifesting dignified conduct while internally truly being fulfilled.

There are bodhisattvas who attain the spiritual power of the divine eye, universally observing the immeasurable buddhas of the ten directions, consulting with them about what they have not heard and entertaining themselves.

There are bodhisattvas who attain the spiritual power of the divine ear, universally hearing various sounds and discerning good and evil, going to them and able to deliver them, preventing them from falling.
There are bodhisattvas who attain the spiritual power of knowing others' minds, using their spiritual powers to go and deliver them.

There are bodhisattvas who attain the spiritual power of knowing past lives, knowing their own past lives and also knowing where other people have come from, taming them according to their kind without falling into extremes.
There are bodhisattvas who attain the supernormal power of ending outflows and can sever all beings' bonds and fetters.
There are bodhisattvas who sit under the king of trees and attain the Buddha's spiritual powers and dignified deportment, perfecting dignified deportment, lineage, parents, and home life.
There are beings who attain the Buddha's radiance, abide in the Buddha's abode, and progress with a mind like the waxing moon.
There are beings who abide in the stage of the Buddha's wisdom and can use the sword of wisdom to sever the dust and defilements.

In this way, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas attain the seventy-five dharmas, the TathÄgata's profound treasury, and inconceivable practices, and attain buddhahood without ever regressing, which is also beyond the reach of arhats and pratyekabuddhas.
In this way, Heavenly Son!

If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas attain this assembly of practices and concentration, they can cause the trichiliocosm to be all the color of gold, and summon all kinds of beings, all turning towards the unsurpassed, true path.
In this way, Heavenly Son!
You should use this Dharma to teach and transform sentient beings, and then you will accord with the bodhisattva precepts.
There are also bodhisattvas who cultivate twelve dharmas, whose practice is unobstructed, and who advance and retreat, coming and going, cultivating the bodhisattva path.
What are the twelve?
First, subduing the troops of MÄra and manifesting the practices of the ten powers;
Second, having the thought of non-arising and non-cessation in common with meritorious virtues;
Third, being able to fulfill all wishes with spiritual powers;
Fourth, relying on the power of non-attachment to see the Buddha's transformations;
Fifth, being able to give to all without regret or stinginess, according to the wholesome roots and merits one has planted;
Sixth, cultivating the foremost Dharma, surpassing the measure of the Buddha;
Seventh, knowing that birth is suffering and not being tainted by the three existences;
Eighth, entertaining oneself with the inexhaustible fundamental path;
Ninth, knowing the practices of the Å›rÄvakas and not being attached to them;
Tenth, knowing the pratyekabuddha Dharma and abandoning it without following it;
Eleventh, practicing the path of non-obstruction and the nine sequential stages;
Twelfth, one should transform one's parents and relatives to achieve accomplishment.
This is called, Heavenly Son!
The twelve unobstructed pure paths, the bodhisattva should contemplate and cultivate to accomplish the fruit of the path.

Heavenly Son, you should know that the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva should cultivate single-minded concentration, and know that the extinction of conceptualization has ten matters, knowing the past, future, and present, just as the Buddha practices without difference.
What is meant by knowing that the extinction of conceptualization has ten matters?

First, contemplating that the original form and appearance of matter does not exist, and also not being attached to giving rise to the concept of form, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva is just like the Buddha practices without difference.
At that time, the bodhisattva cultivates the perfection of the excellent characteristics, and for each excellent characteristic, it is just like the Buddha practices without difference.
The bodhisattva's spiritual wisdom transforms without bounds, responding to sentient beings and going to liberate them according to conditions, just like the Buddha practices without difference.

At that time, the Bodhisattva transformed into immeasurable bodies with the foremost appearance and with the eight kinds of sounds, guiding sentient beings, just like the Buddha's practice without any difference.

Moreover, that Bodhisattva purified the Buddha-lands, observed the thoughts and intentions of sentient beings, and did not violate the precepts in his dignified deportment, just like the Buddha's practice without any difference.

At that time, the Bodhisattva again entered the state of concentration and samÄdhi, able to remember the sounds and echoes of sentient beings with precise recollection without forgetting, just like the Buddha's practice without any difference.

Moreover, that Bodhisattva practiced the ten kinds of wisdom, which were limitless, immeasurable, and inexhaustible, and also caused sentient beings to study this fundamental Dharma, adapting to the times and turning the unsurpassed Dharma wheel, just like the Buddha's practice without any difference.

Moreover, those bodhisattvas attain the four forms of fearlessness, and in the great assembly they roar the lion's roar, not cutting off the TathÄgata's true Dharma, and further using this Dharma to teach and transform sentient beings, all of whom accomplish and attain the unsurpassed path, attaining omniscience without obstruction, just as the Buddha practices without any difference.

Moreover, the teachings expounded by those bodhisattvas pervade everywhere and enter the practices of the three times, exhausting all afflictions and accomplishing the practice of being free from outflows. With the wisdom of spiritual powers, they are able to transform everything, just as the Buddha practices.

Moreover, those bodhisattvas attain the Buddha's fearlessness and are fully endowed with the ten powers. They see the purity of the Buddha-lands and sentient beings, just as the Buddha practices without any difference.
In this way, Heavenly Son!
If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice these ten things, they will progress and accomplish buddhahood without difficulty.
Why is it so?

All dharmas are originally non-existent, neither coming nor going, dharmas are without characteristics, and characteristics are also non-existent, dharmas are without sound, and sound is originally formless, the inherent nature is originally empty.
Why is it so?
Sound arises from emptiness and returns to emptiness, sentient beings' defilements arise from the conceptualization of consciousness.
Heavenly son, you should know that when I was seeking the Way, for innumerable eons I analyzed the beginning and end, but was unable to thoroughly understand a single dharma and attain concentration.
What is that one dharma?
It is called non-thought.
Bodhisattvas who attain the concentration of non-thought contemplate all dharmas as being formless.
It is like this, Heavenly Son!
I have now attained Buddhahood, and through this one practice I have attained the unsurpassed true Way.
At that time, the Heavenly Son of the Pure Abode addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

What I hear now is that the practices of the bodhisattvas are immeasurable and difficult to fathom. Sentient beings have various faculties and are not the same. How can one wish to attain the unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment?
Moreover, I have heard the Buddha say that the practices of the Buddha are without distinction.
I now ask the TathÄgata, how are the practices of the Buddha without distinction?
I only wish that the World-Honored One will explain this in detail.
At that time, the celestial son again addressed the Buddha, saying:
The practices of the bodhisattvas are each different. Their aspirations and the traces of their practices are not the same.
Why is it so?
World-Honored One!
If the practices of the bodhisattvas are not different from those of the Buddha, why are they not called Buddhas?
Why do they not possess the ten powers and subdue the palace of MÄra?
Why are they not called omniscient?
Why are they not called those who have awakened to all dharmas?
Why are they not called those who thoroughly contemplate the bodhisattva path?
Why do you not sit in the Buddha's place and proclaim the causes and conditions?
Why are you not called the Most Perfectly Enlightened One?
Why is it so?
Do you not know the right Dharma of the three times practiced by all Buddhas?
Why do you not abide in life for an eon and proclaim wisdom?
Why do you not rely on and abide in all dharmas to cultivate right concentration?
Why do you not discern the Dharma realm and advance immeasurable wisdom, teaching and admonishing bodhisattvas as your retinue?
At that time, the World-Honored One told the Heavenly Son of Pure Abode:
Excellent, excellent!
Son of a good family!
What you have asked has already surpassed all measures. I will now explain it to you.
Listen carefully, listen carefully, and consider it well!
Heavenly Son!

Now, I ask about the practice of the bodhisattva, which is no different from that of the Buddha. All good men and good women, who have realized that all dharmas are formless and invisible, the bodhisattva's great vows extend to all sentient beings of the past, future, and present, who are in a state of mutual dependence and have not yet attained the pure contemplation of wisdom. If they were to attain wisdom, they would be called the TathÄgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, relying on the wisdom of the bodhisattva to transform and liberate sentient beings, and having attained it themselves, they would bestow it upon others. This is called the bodhisattva path, which can eradicate the three poisons, not give rise to the ten evil deeds, and exhaust the realm of the TathÄgata. This is called the ten powers.
Having already transcended the ordinary person and established the traces of bodhisattva practice, the mind does not waver from the unsurpassed true path. This is called a bodhisattva.
If there are good men and good women who discern the dharma realm and mutually accept and include each other, this is called omniscience.

Just as all phenomena are originally without characteristics or appearances, but due to sentient beings they each have names and forms, which can be known and abandoned as appropriate, without departing from the fundamental goodness, cultivating the bodhisattva path, this is called a bodhisattva.
Just as a bodhisattva distinguishes between one and two, naturally giving rise to the perfections.
Again, he himself realizes and causes the multitude to share the same Dharma characteristics, this is called a buddha.
Just as that bodhisattva does not see the arising of two or three phenomena, he observes well, does not forget, contemplates and understands, from where do phenomena arise?
From where do phenomena cease?
Who is it that turns the wheel of Dharma?
Who hears the Dharma?
One who is able to understand and know all phenomena, this is called a bodhisattva.

It is like a bodhisattva who with the eye of wisdom observes the three thousand great one thousand worlds, with minds of desire and without minds of desire, with minds of delusion and without minds of delusion, with minds of anger and without minds of anger, and is able to contemplate and completely sever the roots, this is called the eye of wisdom.

Furthermore, the bodhisattva with the eye of wisdom goes back and forth, traveling through the Buddha-lands, completely knowing the thoughts in the minds of sentient beings who are to be liberated and those who are not, and is able to enter and transform according to their kind and liberate them, this is called a bodhisattva.

It is like a bodhisattva who with various lights universally illuminates all realms, demonstrating immeasurable wisdom, and recollects the profound Dharma of the Buddhas, World-Honored Ones, this is called a bodhisattva.

Just as a bodhisattva can illuminate the realm of space with the light of wisdom, the TathÄgata's spiritual knowledge is present, closing the door to wrongdoing and opening the path to nirvÄá¹‡a, and yet he is not attached to the eighteen fundamental precepts, being without attachment and without bondage. This is called a bodhisattva.ğŸ”½Just as a bodhisattva cultivates and distinguishes himself with the Buddha's dignified deportment, the TathÄgata walks alone without a companion, and yet he knows the past, present, and future of sentient beings, their origins and ends, one by one. This is called having no equal.

Just as a bodhisattva succeeds the TathÄgata and does not cut off the Buddha's lineage, performing the Buddha's work, the born do not know birth, and the extinguished do not know extinction. Originally non-existent and tranquil, endowed with the four immeasurable minds, he also distinguishes what was originally non-existent but now exists, and what was originally existent but now does not exist. Understanding that everything is empty, he does not give rise to various thoughts. Therefore, he is called the Buddha.

It is like a bodhisattva who attains the wisdom of spiritual powers and observes sentient beings, whether their kalpas are near or far. He is not discouraged by distant kalpas and not delighted by near kalpas. The formation and destruction of kalpas are also like this. He concentrates his mind and holds his thoughts without confusion. Therefore, he is called a bodhisattva.
The Buddha further told the Heavenly Son of Pure Abode:

If good men and good women practice the bodhisattva path, they should further contemplate all dharmas, from the initial arousal of the mind up to the attainment of Buddhahood. They should not conceive of self, self, person, or lifespan. Their practice should naturally eliminate all defilements. This is called cultivating the bodhisattva path.

There are also bodhisattvas who arouse the aspiration for the path for the sake of all sentient beings and take on the practice of suffering. They also do not see anyone who attains the path, yet they are able to deliver innumerable sentient beings beyond measure. Some attain realization, while others do not. Within this, they receive predictions without being attached. This is called cultivating the bodhisattva path.
Furthermore, Heavenly Son!
If good men and good women discern the immeasurable and profound Dharma of the three emptinesses and know it as it truly is.
What are the three emptinesses?
First, with perception and thought;
Second, without perception but with thought;
Third, without perception and without thought.
These are called the three emptinesses, which are practiced by the bodhisattvas.
He further told the Heavenly Son:
There are also three emptinesses.
What are the three?
First, emptiness of exhaustion;
Second, emptiness of non-exhaustion;
Third, emptiness of neither exhaustion nor non-exhaustion.
These are called the three emptinesses, which are practiced by the bodhisattvas.
The Buddha further told the Heavenly Son:
There are also three emptinesses:
First, emptiness of arising;
Second, emptiness of non-arising;
Third, emptiness of neither arising nor non-arising.
These are called the three emptinesses, which are practiced by the bodhisattvas.
The Buddha further told the Heavenly Son:
There are also three emptinesses:
What are the three?
First, abiding in emptiness;
Second, non-abiding emptiness;
Third, neither abiding nor non-abiding emptiness.
At that time, the god-son of the Pure Abode addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
Past, future, and present dharmas, all sentient beings have birth and cessation, attachment and cutting off. Do they have these three kinds of emptiness or not?
The Buddha told the god-son:
I will now explain to you, contemplate it well!
What is meant by abiding in emptiness?
It refers to abiding in emptiness, which is unconditioned and tranquil.
God-son, you should know, what is meant by non-abiding emptiness?
It refers to your body and mine.
What is meant by neither abiding nor non-abiding emptiness?
It refers to all forms and dharmas of the three times.
The Buddha further told the god-son:

If good men and good women understand these three kinds of emptiness, they will be able to thoroughly understand all dharmas. The five aggregates of clinging are also like this. This is called the bodhisattva path.
The Buddha further told the celestial son:
All dharmas are neither combined nor scattered. One does not see purity or impurity. One also does not think to oneself:
'When I attain Buddhahood, I will be born in such and such a place, in such and such a country, prefecture, county, with such and such parents, relatives, clan, and name.'
One also does not think:
'I will be born in such and such a kalpa with such and such a lifespan.'
One also does not think to oneself:
'Sitting under a flower tree with a golden body, I will attain the unsurpassed perfect true Way.'
This is called the bodhisattva path. One is then able to fully possess the non-retrogressive mind of no birth, with no single characteristic, let alone two characteristics.

At that time, the Bodhisattva contemplated that all phenomena return to emptiness and tranquility. He always guarded himself and did not give the evil demons an opportunity. He went nowhere and turned nowhere. In this way, he had already entered the immeasurable empty wisdom of the Dharma realm and was able to adorn himself with the Dharma of various characteristics.
The Buddha further told the celestial son:

Just as the eyes and forms have no owner inside or outside, the three things come together to form eye-consciousness. Feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are also like this. The internal and external are accomplished to form various consciousnesses.
The Buddha told the celestial son:
I will now draw an analogy for you. The wise understand through analogies.

It is like the dragon king Elapattra, who resides on the side of the Golden Fortunate Mountain. His jeweled palace is made of the seven treasures, the jeweled walls are made of the seven treasures, and the jeweled trees are also made of the seven treasures. The stairs, steps, and streets are all made of the seven treasures, carved and inlaid with various treasures.
At that time, the king of the Airavana dragons had a body as pure white as snow and jade, with a golden canopy following behind, his body fragrant, and all his necklaces made of the seven treasures.
He also used the seven treasures to make his eating utensils, and a flower garland was made of pure purple gold.

He also used the seven treasures to make bells, drums, and musical instruments, and his seven orifices were level and his teeth were even. His appearance was dignified, and one never tired of looking at him. He was pure and fragrant, and when he turned left and right, he did not touch anything. He had these many virtues that were immeasurable.

However, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, the most honored among the thirty-three devas, if he had something in mind, in the time it takes to snap one's fingers, he could cause the king of the Airavana dragons on the side of the Golden Fortunate Mountain to go to the Heaven of the Thirty-three in the time it takes to bend and extend one's arm, and his attendants and servants would immediately arrive without obstruction.
At that time, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, wanting to cause the devas to witness his merits, immediately adorned the dragon's body with the seven treasures.

At that time, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, would ride this divine dragon to roam about in the east and west. At that time, the dragon king IrÄpatra would also use his spiritual powers to transform and create various offerings to serve and respectfully attend to Åšakra, Lord of the Devas.

The dragon would transform his own form into thirty-two heads, with seven tusks on each head, and on each tusk there would be seven bathing pools, with seven hundred lotus flowers in each pool, and on each flower there would be seven hundred celestial maidens, and each celestial maiden would bring seven hundred attendants, playing music and entertainment together to amuse themselves.

If the heavenly king Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, wished to take a break, he would go to the back of the seven-jeweled palace to a bathing pool called Fragrant and Pure, and personally enter the bathing pool to ride the dragon king IrÄpatra and indulge in play.

At that time, the Heavenly King Åšakra, having entered a beautiful bathing pond riding this dragon, adorned his body with various treasures, played music and enjoyed the five desires by himself, and the joy of mutual entertainment was indescribable.

At that time, the Dragon King IrÄpatana abandoned his original form and did not transform his body into a dragon's body. With his own spiritual power, he transformed into the appearance of the Thirty-three Heavens, and again entered a bathing pond, together with the heavenly maidens, and enjoyed himself, just like Heavenly Emperor Åšakra, without any difference.

Those on the left and right observed this transformation, and the heavenly bodies and dragon bodies were each no different. The body was the same as the heavenly body, and the color was the same as the heavenly color. They were together in a bathing pond without any change. The body of Åšakra and the body of the dragon were one, not two.
Why is this?
It is all due to the merit accumulated from past lives.

If these two people originally sought the unsurpassed true path, they will also soon attain Buddhahood today. Practice comes from the mind, and when the mind is pure, the path is accomplished. Just like the heavenly palace, one does not know where it originally came from, and when it goes, there is nowhere it goes. All practices are empty and still.
Heavenly son, you should know that your present body, the heavenly palace, the sun, and the moon will all return to destruction and cannot be kept forever.
Therefore, heavenly son!

You should understand the nature of dharmas, the direction of formation and destruction, the constant division of arising and ceasing. Only nirvana is the most peaceful and wonderful, not something that can be destroyed by swords, spells, or magic.
